Please register in the waitlist for the lower-level version of this ensemble. You’ll receive information about the audition process and if you’re admitted, we’ll make sure you’re in the correct ensemble course code.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: This course is for PIAN and GMUS piano students who seek to deepen their understanding and capacities in the realm of sight-reading, applicable for quick-learning, performance collaborations, and teaching skills. Designed as a small group class with individual coachings, it comprises discussion and exploration of the multiple skills engaged when playing piano music at first sight. The class is a supportive and non-competitive environment, blending experiential discoveries of tools and means, reflections on cognitive obstacles, and confidence-building discussions. The weekly sessions build new understanding of piano sight-reading by examining its components separately and combining them with new awareness of its multi-layered process.No pre-req, can be taken in any year.General Studies Piano Concentrators - please submit a registration request for support with registration: https://ubc.ca1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_cIvdTe2ov1zJ1Ns

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
The Nordic societies today are best known for their rankings on the global happiness scale, but what makes them so happy? Is it the constant state of anxiety they endure? Is it their not-so-healthy relationship with death? Could it be their insistence on exposing their children to scary and taboo subjects? In this course we scour the strange and unsettling world of Nordic fiction through themes like death, anxiety and folklore to find the key to true Nordic happiness.

Sample syllabus here.

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Cross-listed with CENS 203. In the face of new and unprecedented environmental and economic challenges in the Arctic, Indigenous peoples have mounted resistance efforts both inside and outside their communities to retain sovereignty over their lands and ways of life. This course explores the neocolonialism of circumpolar regions, and looks at the ways that Indigenous peoples have engaged in resistance and revitalization through collective action and art. Meets the Place and Power requirement. 

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Pre-reqs: 6 credits each first year BIOL and CHEM. Students not meeting the pre-requisites will be dropped from the course.
Students In - Any Specializations in B.H.K (Vancouver), Any Specializations in B.KIN (Vancouver), B.Sc., Honours in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (Vancouver), B.Sc., Major in Biology (Vancouver), B.Sc., Major in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (Vancouver), B.Sc., Major in Integrated Sciences (Vancouver), B.Sc., Major in Microbiology and Immunology (Vancouver), B.Sc., Major in Pharmacology (Vancouver), Bachelor of Human Kinetics (Vancouver), Bachelor of Kinesiology (Vancouver), Bachelor of Science (Vancouver), Bachelor of Science in Applied Biology (Vancouver), Bachelor of Science in Food, Nutrition, and Health (Vancouver), B.Sc. Honours in Integrated Sciences (Vancouver), Major in Pharmacology (Vancouver), B.Sc., Major in Behavioural Neuroscience (Vancouver), B.Sc., Major in Neuroscience (Vancouver), Major in Behavioural Neuroscience (Vancouver), Major in Neuroscience (Vancouver) AND 3rd, 4th, 5th Year

LOCATION: LSC 1001/1002; NO CLASS SEPTEMBER 3 in lieu of Imagine Day.
FIRST LECTURE SEPTEMBER 5 in LSC 1002.
BEING ON THE WAITLIST DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU A SPACE IN THE COURSE. Please do not contact course instructors about registration issues; course registrations/waitlists are managed by the program office. The waitlist is managed by checking students meet the pre-requisites and chronologically checking the waitlist for the first student who can fit the course into their timetable.  IF THERE IS A TIMETABLE CONFLICT YOU WILL NOT BE REGISTERED IN THE COURSE.
It is the student's responsibility to check for registration changes.  Information on wait-list positioning will not be provided.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous multi-access course. Students are expected to meet on the days and times listed, either in-person or online.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
